dt: {bc}to wear out by overwork or abuse
{bc}to tire or dull through repetition or excess

pt: {sc}tire{/sc} {sc}weary{/sc} {sc}fatigue{/sc} {sc}exhaust{/sc} {sc}jade{/sc} mean to make or become unable or unwilling to continue. {sc}tire{/sc} implies a draining of one's strength or patience.
{sc}weary{/sc} stresses tiring until one is unable to endure more of the same thing.
{sc}fatigue{/sc} suggests great lassitude from excessive strain or undue effort.
{sc}exhaust{/sc} implies complete draining of strength by hard exertion.
{sc}jade{/sc} suggests the loss of all freshness and eagerness.

pt: {sc}tire{/sc} {sc}weary{/sc} {sc}fatigue{/sc} {sc}exhaust{/sc} {sc}jade{/sc} mean to make or become unable or unwilling to continue. {sc}tire{/sc} implies a draining of one's strength or patience.
{sc}weary{/sc} stresses tiring until one is unable to endure more of the same thing.
{sc}fatigue{/sc} suggests great lassitude from excessive strain or undue effort.
{sc}exhaust{/sc} implies complete draining of strength by hard exertion.
{sc}jade{/sc} suggests the loss of all freshness and eagerness.

dt.t: … the "literary" fiction being written in this country nowadays strikes me as so {wi}jejune{/wi}, self-absorbed and lifeless that I am just about unable to read it, much less pass fair judgment on it.

pt: {sc}insipid{/sc} {sc}vapid{/sc} {sc}flat{/sc} {sc}jejune{/sc} {sc}banal{/sc} {sc}inane{/sc} mean devoid of qualities that make for spirit and character. {sc}insipid{/sc} implies a lack of sufficient taste or savor to please or interest.

pt.t: an {it}insipid{/it} romance with platitudes on every page

pt: {sc}vapid{/sc} suggests a lack of liveliness, force, or spirit.

pt.t: an exciting story given a {it}vapid{/it} treatment

pt: {sc}flat{/sc} applies to things that have lost their sparkle or zest.

pt.t: although well-regarded in its day, the novel now seems {it}flat{/it}

pt: {sc}jejune{/sc} suggests a lack of rewarding or satisfying substance.
{sc}banal{/sc} stresses the complete absence of freshness, novelty, or immediacy.
{sc}inane{/sc} implies a lack of any significant or convincing quality.

shortdef: devoid of significance or interest : dull

pt: {sc}fun{/sc} {sc}jest{/sc} {sc}sport{/sc} {sc}game{/sc} {sc}play{/sc} mean action or speech that provides amusement or arouses laughter. {sc}fun{/sc} usually implies laughter or gaiety but may imply merely a lack of serious or ulterior purpose.
{sc}jest{/sc} implies lack of earnestness and may suggest a hoaxing or teasing.

pt.t: hurt by remarks said only in {it}jest{/it}

{sc}play{/sc} stresses the opposition to {it}earnest{/it} without implying any malice or mischief.

pt.t: pretended to strangle his brother in {it}play{/it}

et: Middle English {it}gest, geste, jeste{/it} "chivalric romance, tale, heroic deed, exploit, action, amusement," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}geste{/it} "heroic deed, romance, tale," borrowed from Latin {it}gesta{/it} "deeds, exploits," plural of {it}gestum{/it} "something carried out," noun derivative from neuter of {it}gestus,{/it} past participle of {it}gerere{/it} "to carry, bear, conduct one's business, act, perform, do," from a verb stem {it}ges-{/it} of uncertain origin

The current senses of {it}jest{/it} date from the 16th century. The Latin verb stem {it}ges-{/it} is without evident Indo-European congeners. An old suggestion that it derives from {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}ǵ-es-,{/it} an extended form containing the zero grade of {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eǵ-{/it} "drive" (see {et_link|agent|agent}) has been revived (as, for example, by Michiel de Vaan in {it}Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the Other Italic Languages,{/it} Brill, 2008; the original suggestion was by Hermann Osthoff in {it}Beiträge zur Kunde der indogermanischen Sprachen,{/it} Band 19 [1893], pp. 320-22.) Parallel formations adduced by Osthoff are, however, questionable, as {it}*u̯es-{/it} (see {et_link|wear:1|wear:1}) from {it}*eu̯-{/it} "put on (footwear)," not possible if the root is actually {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eu̯(H)-{/it} (see {et_link|exuviae|exuviae}). Latin {it}ger-{/it} is unlikely to have any relation to Old Norse {it}kǫr{/it} "heap, pile," {it}kǫstr{/it} "pile," {it}kasta{/it} "to throw, fling" (see {et_link|cast:1|cast:1}).
shortdef: a joking or mocking remark

dt: {bc}racial {d_link|segregation|segregation} and discrimination enforced by laws, customs, and practices in especially the southern states of the U.S. from the end of {d_link|Reconstruction|reconstruction} in 1877 until the mid-20th century

dt.t: The percentage of blacks living in the South fell from 89 percent in 1910 to 53 percent in 1970 as millions migrated to the Northeast and Midwest to escape {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} and acquire a better standard of life.

dt: {bc}the laws requiring racial segregation that were enacted under Jim Crow

dt.t: The explicit sanctioning of segregation by {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} meant that black public schools lacked of resources and public funding—shortcomings that limited the skill sets and education levels of young, black men during this period, which in turn limited their job opportunities.
It took the Civil War, the Fourteenth Amendment, and the repeal of {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} for the most egalitarian society on earth even to begin to narrow the gulf between principle and practice.

All the women … who marched or canvassed during the civil rights movement helped bring about the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the 1965 Voting Rights Act, which ended {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} and enfranchised Southern blacks.

In 1926, while traveling by train from Wilmington, N.C., to Richmond, Va., the Jamaican-American writer J. A. Rogers was forced to ride in the wooden {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} car {gloss}=segregated car required by Jim Crow laws{/gloss}, which was typically placed toward the front, behind the engine and ahead of the steel cars reserved for white passengers.

Although such segregation has been banned since the late 1960s by federal, state and local public accommodations laws, civil rights activists say {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} still exists here, largely unnoticed and unchallenged.

dt: {bc}racism personified {bc}racist systems or beliefs imagined as a person

dt.t: But [Congressman George H.] White understood that, in fact, {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} was determined to maintain the power structure of the plantation economy by any means necessary.

aq.auth: William J. Barber II and Jonathan Wilson-Hartgrove

dt.t: But in 1883 the Supreme Court had cast aside the law, saying that not even the equal protection clause of the 14th amendment gave the Congress the power to outlaw racial discrimination among private individuals. That is one of the openings via which {wi}Jim Crow{/wi} dug in after the end of slavery.

pt: {sc}witty{/sc} {sc}humorous{/sc} {sc}facetious{/sc} {sc}jocular{/sc} {sc}jocose{/sc} mean provoking or intended to provoke laughter. {sc}witty{/sc} suggests cleverness and quickness of mind.
{sc}humorous{/sc} applies broadly to anything that evokes usually genial laughter and may contrast with {it}witty{/it} in suggesting whimsicality or eccentricity.
{sc}facetious{/sc} stresses a desire to produce laughter and may be derogatory in implying dubious or ill-timed attempts at wit or humor.
{sc}jocular{/sc} implies a usually habitual fondness for jesting and joking.
{sc}jocose{/sc} is somewhat less derogatory than {sc}facetious{/sc} in suggesting habitual waggishness or playfulness.

shortdef: given to joking : merry
characterized by joking : humorous

pt: {sc}witty{/sc} {sc}humorous{/sc} {sc}facetious{/sc} {sc}jocular{/sc} {sc}jocose{/sc} mean provoking or intended to provoke laughter. {sc}witty{/sc} suggests cleverness and quickness of mind.
{sc}humorous{/sc} applies broadly to anything that evokes usually genial laughter and may contrast with {it}witty{/it} in suggesting whimsicality or eccentricity.
{sc}facetious{/sc} stresses a desire to produce laughter and may be derogatory in implying dubious or ill-timed attempts at wit or humor.
{sc}jocular{/sc} implies a usually habitual fondness for jesting and joking.
{sc}jocose{/sc} is somewhat less derogatory than {sc}facetious{/sc} in suggesting habitual waggishness or playfulness.

shortdef: said or done as a joke : characterized by jesting : playful
given to jesting : habitually jolly or jocund

dt: {bc}a wholesome joke of the type said to be told by fathers with a punchline that is often an obvious or predictable pun or play on words and usually judged to be endearingly corny or unfunny

dt.t: He's seen the annual event grow from an Austin oddity to a national event and watched {wi}dad jokes{/wi}, of which puns are the most obvious example, take hold in the millennial consciousness; a {wi}dad-joke{/wi}-devoted Reddit board boasts more than 250,000 members.

The {wi}dad jokes{/wi} really started pouring in during the later years of Obama's presidency, when the annual turkey pardoning became fertile grounds for embarrassing the now teenage Malia and Sasha. And what better way to do that than with some corny puns about turkeys named Mac and Cheese?

dt: {bc}a formulaic joke that begins with the words {ldquo}Knock knock{rdquo} in imitation of someone knocking on a door

The standard pattern of a knock-knock joke calls for a response of {ldquo}Who's there?{rdquo}, a cryptic reply identifying the knocker, a further response repeating the name of the knocker followed by {ldquo}who?{rdquo}, and a final joking reply typically featuring a pun or play on words.

dt.t: William Cole … is a perpetrator of, and authority on, the {wi}knock-knock joke{/wi}. {ldquo}{wi}Knock-knock jokes{/wi} are basically puns, that's all, and you've got to have a feel for the ludicrous,{rdquo} he says. …. he considers the following to be his best creation: {ldquo}Knock knock.{rdquo} Who's there? {ldquo}Amaryllis.{rdquo} Amaryllis who? {ldquo}Amaryllis state agent. Wanna buy a house?{rdquo}

Big Bird to audience: {ldquo}You're having fun, right? Okay, let's do a {wi}knock-knock joke{/wi}. Knock knock.{rdquo} Audience: {ldquo}Who's there?{rdquo} BB: {ldquo}Ya.{rdquo} Audience: {ldquo}Ya who?{rdquo} BB: {ldquo}See, I told you you were having fun.{rdquo} Groan if you like, but it's a hoot to a 4-year-old.

shortdef: a formulaic joke that begins with the words "Knock knock" in imitation of someone knocking on a door

dt.t: {wi}By jove{/wi}, Randal, how pleasant a thing is life in London!
"{wi}By jove{/wi}, Lily, you do look a stunner!"
… I've made up my mind to one thing, and, {wi}by Jove{/wi}, I'll stick to it.
They are not attractive … and nor are they particularly comfortable or cheap, but {wi}by Jove{/wi} they work.
… a setting in which one fully expects to overhear such expletives as Egad! or {wi}By Jove{/wi}! or Bully! …

shortdef: jupiter

pt: {sc}merry{/sc} {sc}blithe{/sc} {sc}jocund{/sc} {sc}jovial{/sc} {sc}jolly{/sc} mean showing high spirits or lightheartedness. {sc}merry{/sc} suggests cheerful, joyous, uninhibited enjoyment of frolic or festivity.
{sc}blithe{/sc} suggests carefree, innocent, or even heedless gaiety.

pt.t: arrived late in his usual {it}blithe{/it} way

pt: {sc}jocund{/sc} stresses elation and exhilaration of spirits.
{sc}jovial{/sc} suggests the stimulation of conviviality and good fellowship.

pt.t: dinner put them in a {it}jovial{/it} mood

pt: {sc}jolly{/sc} suggests high spirits expressed in laughing, bantering, and jesting.

quotes.t: I felt I was slumming, in my own life. My task was to ward off the drivel … the {qword}jovial{/qword} claptrap of classmates and teachers, the maddening bromides I heard at home.
For, the people who were shovelling away on the housetops were {qword}jovial{/qword} and full of glee; calling out to one another from the parapets, and now and then exchanging a facetious snowball …
In response, an infuriating wink: Alsana always likes to appear {qword}jovial{/qword} at the very moment that her interlocutor becomes hot under the collar.

shortdef: characterized by good-humored cheerfulness and conviviality : jolly
of or relating to Jove

pt: {sc}juncture{/sc} {sc}exigency{/sc} {sc}emergency{/sc} {sc}contingency{/sc} {sc}pinch{/sc} {sc}strait{/sc} ({it}or{/it} {sc}straits{/sc}) {sc}crisis{/sc} mean a critical or crucial time or state of affairs. {sc}juncture{/sc} stresses the significant concurrence or convergence of events.

pt.t: an important {it}juncture{/it} in our country's history

pt: {sc}exigency{/sc} stresses the pressure of restrictions or urgency of demands created by a special situation.
{sc}emergency{/sc} applies to a sudden unforeseen situation requiring prompt action to avoid disaster.

pt.t: the presence of mind needed to deal with {it}emergencies{/it}

pt: {sc}contingency{/sc} implies an emergency or exigency that is regarded as possible but uncertain of occurrence.
{sc}pinch{/sc} implies urgency or pressure for action to a less intense degree than {sc}exigency{/sc} or {sc}emergency{/sc}.
{sc}strait{/sc}, now commonly {sc}straits{/sc}, applies to a troublesome situation from which escape is extremely difficult.
{sc}crisis{/sc} applies to a juncture whose outcome will make a decisive difference.

shortdef: a point of time; especially : one made critical by a concurrence of circumstances

pt: {sc}discard{/sc} {sc}cast{/sc} {sc}shed{/sc} {sc}slough{/sc} {sc}scrap{/sc} {sc}junk{/sc} mean to get rid of. {sc}discard{/sc} implies the letting go or throwing away of something that has become useless or superfluous though often not intrinsically valueless.
{sc}cast{/sc}, especially when used with {it}off, away{/it}, or {it}out{/it}, implies a forceful rejection or repudiation.
{sc}shed{/sc} and {sc}slough{/sc} imply a throwing off of something both useless and encumbering and often suggest a consequent renewal of vitality or luster.
{sc}scrap{/sc} and {sc}junk{/sc} imply throwing away or breaking up as worthless in existent form.

shortdef: to get rid of as worthless : scrap

{sc}shed{/sc} and {sc}slough{/sc} imply a throwing off of something both useless and encumbering and often suggest a consequent renewal of vitality or luster.
{sc}scrap{/sc} and {sc}junk{/sc} imply throwing away or breaking up as worthless in existent form.

shortdef: to get rid of as worthless : scrap

pt: {sc}discard{/sc} {sc}cast{/sc} {sc}shed{/sc} {sc}slough{/sc} {sc}scrap{/sc} {sc}junk{/sc} mean to get rid of. {sc}discard{/sc} implies the letting go or throwing away of something that has become useless or superfluous though often not intrinsically valueless.
{sc}cast{/sc}, especially when used with {it}off, away{/it}, or {it}out{/it}, implies a forceful rejection or repudiation.
{sc}shed{/sc} and {sc}slough{/sc} imply a throwing off of something both useless and encumbering and often suggest a consequent renewal of vitality or luster.
{sc}scrap{/sc} and {sc}junk{/sc} imply throwing away or breaking up as worthless in existent form.

shortdef: to get rid of as worthless : scrap

pt: {sc}fair{/sc} {sc}just{/sc} {sc}equitable{/sc} {sc}impartial{/sc} {sc}unbiased{/sc} {sc}dispassionate{/sc} {sc}objective{/sc} mean free from favor toward either or any side. {sc}fair{/sc} implies a proper balance of conflicting interests.
{sc}just{/sc} implies an exact following of a standard of what is right and proper.
{sc}equitable{/sc} implies a less rigorous standard than {sc}just{/sc} and usually suggests equal treatment of all concerned.
{sc}impartial{/sc} stresses an absence of favor or prejudice.
{sc}unbiased{/sc} implies even more strongly an absence of all prejudice.
{sc}dispassionate{/sc} suggests freedom from the influence of strong feeling and often implies cool or even cold judgment.
{sc}objective{/sc} stresses a tendency to view events or persons as apart from oneself and one's own interest or feelings.

pt.t: I can't be {it}objective{/it} about my own child

pt: {sc}upright{/sc} {sc}honest{/sc} {sc}just{/sc} {sc}conscientious{/sc} {sc}scrupulous{/sc} {sc}honorable{/sc} mean having or showing a strict regard for what is morally right. {sc}upright{/sc} implies a strict adherence to moral principles.
{sc}honest{/sc} stresses adherence to such virtues as truthfulness, candor, or fairness.

pt.t: known for being {it}honest{/it} in business dealings

pt: {sc}just{/sc} stresses conscious choice and regular practice of what is right or equitable.
{sc}conscientious{/sc} and {sc}scrupulous{/sc} imply an active moral sense governing all one's actions and painstaking efforts to follow one's conscience.

pt.t: {it}conscientious{/it} in the completion of her assignments
{it}scrupulous{/it} in carrying out the terms of the will

pt: {sc}honorable{/sc} suggests a firm holding to codes of right behavior and the guidance of a high sense of honor and duty.

pt: {sc}fair{/sc} {sc}just{/sc} {sc}equitable{/sc} {sc}impartial{/sc} {sc}unbiased{/sc} {sc}dispassionate{/sc} {sc}objective{/sc} mean free from favor toward either or any side. {sc}fair{/sc} implies a proper balance of conflicting interests.
{sc}just{/sc} implies an exact following of a standard of what is right and proper.
{sc}equitable{/sc} implies a less rigorous standard than {sc}just{/sc} and usually suggests equal treatment of all concerned.
{sc}impartial{/sc} stresses an absence of favor or prejudice.
{sc}unbiased{/sc} implies even more strongly an absence of all prejudice.
{sc}dispassionate{/sc} suggests freedom from the influence of strong feeling and often implies cool or even cold judgment.
{sc}objective{/sc} stresses a tendency to view events or persons as apart from oneself and one's own interest or feelings.

pt.t: I can't be {it}objective{/it} about my own child

pt: {sc}upright{/sc} {sc}honest{/sc} {sc}just{/sc} {sc}conscientious{/sc} {sc}scrupulous{/sc} {sc}honorable{/sc} mean having or showing a strict regard for what is morally right. {sc}upright{/sc} implies a strict adherence to moral principles.
{sc}honest{/sc} stresses adherence to such virtues as truthfulness, candor, or fairness.

pt.t: known for being {it}honest{/it} in business dealings

pt: {sc}just{/sc} stresses conscious choice and regular practice of what is right or equitable.
{sc}conscientious{/sc} and {sc}scrupulous{/sc} imply an active moral sense governing all one's actions and painstaking efforts to follow one's conscience.

pt.t: {it}conscientious{/it} in the completion of her assignments
{it}scrupulous{/it} in carrying out the terms of the will

pt: {sc}honorable{/sc} suggests a firm holding to codes of right behavior and the guidance of a high sense of honor and duty.

pt: {sc}adjacent{/sc} {sc}adjoining{/sc} {sc}contiguous{/sc} {sc}juxtaposed{/sc} mean being in close proximity. {sc}adjacent{/sc} may or may not imply contact but always implies absence of anything of the same kind in between.
{sc}adjoining{/sc} definitely implies meeting and touching at some point or line.
{sc}contiguous{/sc} implies having contact on all or most of one side.
{sc}juxtaposed{/sc} means placed side by side especially so as to permit comparison and contrast.
